#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Identify Plastic Rice
#Text=Suspicions about plastic rice being passed off for food went viral in 2017 .
#Text=However , food safety agencies have yet to find any evidence that supports the rumors .
#Text=If you want to stay on the safe side , you can test rice by making sure it sinks in water , boiling it , and heating it on a hot skillet .
#Text=While plastic beads that resemble rice do exist , they ’re primarily used to cushion fragile items during shipping .
#Text=You could purchase some online and set up a fun experiment .
#Text=Try testing plastic and real rice side by side so you can clearly see the differences between them .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Trying the Water Test
#Text=Purchase plastic rice beads if you want a comparison .
#Text=Plastic rice beads are available online and at some art supply stores .
#Text=They ’re used to cushion shipped cargo and for crafts projects .
#Text=When you conduct your experiments , you could compare a sample of plastic rice with the rice you want to test .
#Text=Some people have seen videos of plastic rice beads being produced and assume that they 're made just to be passed off as food .
#Text=However , plastic rice beads are more expensive to produce than actual rice , so it would n’t be profitable to try to substitute plastic for the real thing .
#Text=Add rice to a glass of water .
#Text=If you just want to test a small amount , drop a tablespoon of rice into a glass of water .
#Text=To test a larger batch , add the rice to a large pot and cover it with of water .
#Text=If you ’re also testing a sample of plastic rice , add it to a separate container of water .
#Text=Stir the water and let it settle .
#Text=Mix up the rice and water for a few seconds .
#Text=Then give the mixture about 30 seconds to stop swirling .
#Text=Look for grains that floats to the surface .
#Text=Because of its density , rice sinks in water .
#Text=If any grains float to the surface after the water settles , you should be suspicious .
#Text=The difference will be obvious if you ’re also testing a sample of plastic beads .
#Text=You might see bits and pieces of dirt and other debris float , but all the grains of rice should sink .
#Text=Aside from verifying its authenticity , soaking and rinsing rice before cooking removes impurities and helps separate the grains .
#Text=In the end , you 'll have a fluffier , less sticky bowl of cooked rice .
#Text=Observing Rice as It Boils
#Text=Add rice to a pot or bowl of water .
#Text=Combine equal parts of rice and water , or use whichever ratio you prefer to use when you normally cook rice .
#Text=Use a pot if you ’re boiling the rice on the stovetop , or combine the rice and water in a microwave-safe bowl .
#Text=Use a separate container to boil plastic rice beads if you ’re testing a comparison sample .
#Text=Cook the rice in the microwave or on the stovetop .
#Text=Bring the rice to a boil over medium heat on the stovetop .
#Text=Alternatively , you could microwave the rice on high for about 3 minutes .
#Text=Check the surface for a layer of thick residue .
#Text=If you ’re boiling the rice on the stovetop , check it after about 10 minutes , or take the bowl out of the microwave after 3 minutes .
#Text=Skim the surface with a spoon to check for a layer of plastic residue .
#Text=When boiling rice on the stovetop , you might have to lower the heat to calm a rolling boil so you can see the surface clearly .
#Text=If you ’re testing a sample of plastic , you ’ll be able to skim a thick layer of melted plastic from the surface .
#Text=In addition , unlike rice , the plastic wo n’t start to fluff and absorb the water .
#Text=Rice is starchy , and some stickiness or residue is normal , especially in short-grained varieties .
#Text=However , there ’s a noticeable difference between a thin starchy residue and a thick layer of melted plastic .
#Text=Heating Rice on a Skillet
#Text=Coat a skillet with oil and heat it on the stove .
#Text=A tablespoon of oil should be enough to coat the surface of a skillet .
#Text=Alternatively , you could coat the surface with cooking spray .
#Text=After coating the skillet , set your burner to high heat and get your pan hot .
#Text=Cover the skillet with a single , thin layer of rice .
#Text=When the oil becomes very thin and hot , add rice to the skillet .
#Text=You ’ll need to be able to observe individual grains , so do n’t add too much rice .
#Text=If you ’re testing a sample of plastic rice beads , heat them in a separate skillet .
#Text=Check for grains that contract and melt .
#Text=Plastic will begin to melt after a couple of minutes on the hot skillet .
#Text=Look closely , and if there are any plastic grains , you 'll be able to see them start to change shape and liquefy .
#Text=If you ’re testing samples side by side , you ’ll have no problem seeing the plastic rice beads contract and melt .
#Text=Melting plastic also has a distinct smell , which you ’ll also detect if you ’re testing a sample of plastic rice beads .
#Text=Tips
#Text=There are claims that rice is plastic if it holds its shape and bounces when you roll it into a ball .
#Text=However , rice is made of carbohydrate and protein molecules , which have bouncy characteristics .
#Text=If a rice ball holds its shape and bounces , it ’s probably old , unrinsed , or overcooked .
#Text=Quick Summary
